user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_init:
```c
void
MHD_init (void)
{
#if defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  WSADATA wsd;
#endif /* MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS */

  MHD_set_panic_func (NULL, NULL);

#if defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  if (0 != WSAStartup (MAKEWORD (2, 2), &wsd))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Failed to initialize winsock.\n"));
  if ((2 != LOBYTE (wsd.wVersion)) && (2 != HIBYTE (wsd.wVersion)))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Winsock version 2.2 is not available.\n"));
#endif /* MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS */
#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
#ifdef MHD_HTTPS_REQUIRE_GCRYPT
#if GCRYPT_VERSION_NUMBER < 0x010600
#if GNUTLS_VERSION_NUMBER <= 0x020b00
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS)
  if (0 != gcry_control (GCRYCTL_SET_THREAD_CBS,
                         &gcry_threads_pthread))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Failed to initialise multithreading in libgcrypt.\n"));
#elif defined(MHD_W32_MUTEX_)
  if (0 != gcry_control (GCRYCTL_SET_THREAD_CBS,
                         &gcry_threads_w32))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Failed to initialise multithreading in libgcrypt.\n"));
#endif /* defined(MHD_W32_MUTEX_) */
#endif /* GNUTLS_VERSION_NUMBER <= 0x020b00 */
  gcry_check_version (NULL);
#else
  if (NULL == gcry_check_version ("1.6.0"))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("libgcrypt is too old. MHD was compiled for " \
                  "libgcrypt 1.6.0 or newer.\n"));
#endif
#endif /* MHD_HTTPS_REQUIRE_GCRYPT */
  gnutls_global_init ();
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
  MHD_monotonic_sec_counter_init ();
  MHD_send_init_static_vars_ ();
  MHD_init_mem_pools_ ();
  /* Check whether sizes were correctly detected by configure */
#ifdef _DEBUG
  if (1)
  {
    struct timeval tv;
    mhd_assert (sizeof(tv.tv_sec) == SIZEOF_STRUCT_TIMEVAL_TV_SEC);
  }
#endif /* _DEBUG */
  mhd_assert (sizeof(uint64_t) == SIZEOF_UINT64_T);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_init:
_MHD_EXTERN void
MHD_set_panic_func (MHD_PanicCallback cb,
                    void *cls)
{
  if ((MHD_PanicCallback) NULL != cb)
    mhd_panic = cb;
  else
    mhd_panic = &mhd_panic_std;

  mhd_panic_cls = cls;
}
...
#define MHD_PANIC(msg) do{mhd_panic(mhd_panic_cls,__FILE__,__LINE__,msg);BUILTIN_NOT_REACHED;}while(0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
if (0 != WSAStartup (MAKEWORD (2, 2), &wsd))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Failed to initialize winsock.\n"));

if ((2 != LOBYTE (wsd.wVersion)) && (2 != HIBYTE (wsd.wVersion)))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Winsock version 2.2 is not available.\n"));
explanation:
The rule targets pointers that should be const-qualified when possible. The fragments above involve: (a) an API that stores a user-supplied context pointer (void *cls) and a panic callback pointer, (b) the MHD_PANIC macro invoking the panic routine with __FILE__ and string literals, and (c) calls that pass string literals or addresses of callback structures to library functions. These should be investigated to determine whether the pointer types (callback context, message/filename parameters, callback-table addresses) could and should be declared to point to const-qualified types.

Other fragments in MHD_init do not need investigation for Rule 8.13 because they either do not involve pointers-to-data that could/should be const, or the pointers are used as out-parameters or buffers that the callee is expected to modify. Examples of safe/irrelevant cases include:
- Passing &wsd to WSAStartup: this is an out-parameter that the function initializes, so it must be non-const.
- Calls such as gnutls_global_init(), MHD_monotonic_sec_counter_init(), MHD_send_init_static_vars_(), MHD_init_mem_pools_(): these contain no pointer-to-constant concerns in the shown code.
- Use of NULL literals alone (e.g. passing NULL) is not meaningful by itself for const-qualification without inspecting the target prototype; where it matters the relevant call/prototype is listed above.

Therefore only the listed fragments require further inspection for compliance with MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13.
